div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria weekly as under for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Railways Express Service for VIENNA, BERLIN, PARIS, & LONDON.
S.S. Osmanieh, Thursday 11 a.m. May 9, 23, June 6 and 20.
S.S. Ismailla, Wednesday 4 p.m. May 1, 15, 29. June 12 and 26.
Special express Itinerary arriving Piracus Friday evenings and Constantinople Saturday afternoon omitting, Smyrna and Mitylene ontwards.

The fast steamers Assouan, Minieh and Menzaleh leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caiffa (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damascus), Tripoli, Alexandretta, and Mersina calling fortnightly at Larnaca (Cyprus) and continuing from Beyrout in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli, and Constantinople.
The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express service to Khartoum.
Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai) Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden
For further information refer to the Co.'s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd., HAMBURG-AMERIKA REISE-BUREAU or other Tourist Agencies.

div.head: MISSIONARIES IN THE FAR EAST
div.p: Two remarkable religious gatherings have taken place in China and Japan, which afforded opportunities for the expression of Chinese and Japanese opinion on missionaries and their work. Shanghai has Seen the centre of a remarkable Centenary Conference, whilst at Tokyo the seventh conference of the World's Student Christian Federation has also attracted much attention.

Nearly 1000 missionaries and visitors were present at the former gathering, which lasted two weeks, and decided to recommend the formation of a Federal Union under the title of the Christian Federation of China, with the ultimate object of securing a united Christian Church in China His Excellency Taotai Tong, who attended the conference as the accredited representative of the Imperial Government, in a written speech, obviously sanctioned, says the "Tribune" correspondent, by his superiors, asserted that the general tendency of mankind was towards good rather than eviL Difference in ideas he urged, should not, even in religious matters, exclude charity and toleration. To the Chinese, as well as to the non partisan foreigner, the outstanding fact in connection with missionary effort was the too great dependence on the arm of flesh rather than on the arm of the Lord. To suffer injustice uncomplainingly was more Christian than to exact treaty rights; to suffer injury than to claim pecuniary indemnity ; to pardon the offender than demand chastisement. Until convincing evidence given the Chinese people that methods pursued in the past would not obtain again, an overwhelming negative influence must be felt on missionary efforts. Other features militating against the achievement of missionary ideals were, he said, the lack of social intercourse between Chinese and foreigners, and the assumption of superiority by the latter. Again, missionaries were often deficient in knowledge of Chinese classics.

Over six hundred delegates representing organizations in twenty-five countries, assembled at the Tokyo gathering, the first of its kind to be held in Japan. The delegates received many messages of greeting from officials of high station. The meetings were thronged by ten thousand students, mainly Japanese and Chinese. A Buddhist Conference was summoned in the same city at the same time ; but the New York "Outlook" notes that resolutions expressing its "profound respect" to the gathering of Christians were passed, arm a deputation to convey these resolutions was chosen. Similarly, a Conference of Shinto priests sent a letter to the Christian Conference expressing their sense of the honour which the Federation had shown to Japan by convening in Tokyo. The Press of Japan was emphatic in its expression of goodwill.

The "Kobe Herald," a newspaper printed in English but edited by Japanese, has this to say :—"The fact is, we believe, that both the authorities of Tokyo and the nation at large are coming more and more to recognize the need of encouraging the spread of spiritual and ethical influences to sot as steadying and inspiring forces in the transition from the old ideas to the new through which Japan is passing, and this more particularly among the rising generation, to which the Student Christian Federation especially appeals. The very fact that Japan is so ready to welcome with pleasure and friendship a great Christian organization and to encourage its work among the youth of the land is in itself the strongest of proofs that the Christian missions in this country have in general performed their tasks in a wise, tactful, and beneficent manner."

div.head: Consul of Alexandria
div.p: The Municipality have decided to retake the census of Alexandria.

div.head: Military Examinations
div.p: 13 military candidates successfully passed in the technical examinations held at the Citadel on the l5th, 16th, 17th, 18th and 19th instant.

div.head: Fatal Scorpion Sting
div.p: On Wednesday afternoon, at Boulac, a small native boy whilst playing on a piece of waste ground, was stung by a scorpion, from which he died a short time after.

div.head: Attempted Suicide
div.p: A native living at Saida Zenab shot himself in the chest with a revolver yesterday morning. He has been taken to hospital in a serious condition, and the reason for his mad action is unknown.

div.head: Quarintine
div.p: By order of the Superior Council, dated at Constantinople on 25th instant, all exports from Port Said will be subjected to a 48 hours examination and disinfection in a 'lazaret' of the Ottoman Empire.

div.head: Seizure of Hashish
div.p: A brigade of special police effected a successful raid on a smoking den, in Darb el Guinena, kept by an Italian, named Giovanni Fogramdo, and seized 70 grams of hashish. 35 smokers were arrested.

div.head: Bubonic Plague
div.p: The following cases of bubonic plague were recorded during the past 24 hours:— 3 recoveries at Beni-Mazar, 1 death outside hospital at Damanhour and 2 admissions and 5 deaths in hospital at Esneh. 26 patients are still under treatment.

div.head: Alcohol in the Sudan
div.p: The tax for the rohsa for the retail of alcoholic beverages in the Sudan has been fixed at P.T. 40 per mensem for the province of Khartoum. P.T 30 for the Bed Sea province and P.T 15 for the Bahr el Gazal province. In all other provinces the charge has been fixed at P.T 20.

div.head: Immorality in Cairo
div.p: On Wednesday afternoon Mr. A Raffye, French consul, accompanied by Commandant Quartier, chief of the secret police, together with several cavasses from different consulates, visited many houses of ill fame the Esbekieh Eight persons, who were unable to explain their presence in the buildings, had their names and nationalities noted and were placed under the supervision of the police.

div.head: Alleged Dishonesty
div.p: We are informed that a clerk of the Port and Lighthouses Administration, employed on the coal quay at Mahmoudeh who recently tendered his resignation, has sent a report to the Finance Ministry alleging dishonesty against the captain in charge of the quay. The allegation has been supported by a ghaffir and the Captain and Mulahiz have been placed under arrest, pending further enquiries.

div.head: An Egyptian Author
div.p: Sheikh, el-Sayed-el-Bakri. whose literary fertility is enormous, has just published in Arabic five works which he has submitted to the Khedive, who heartily approved them. The names of these works are "Saharig-el-loulou" Fountain of Pearls): "Beit el Seddik (The House of Truth) Beit-el-Sadat el-Wafaieh : El tàlim wel-ershad" (Education and Guidance): and "Mostakbel el-lslam" The future of Islam. Amongst these new books, the "Fountain of Pearls is a collection of the most eloquent passages from Arabic literature, and the "Future of Islam" is an exceedingly well documented study.

div.head: Mosiem on British Rule
div.p: The Nawab Mohsin-ul-Mulk, a well known Mahometan leader, who has been interviewed on the subject of the present unrest in India said :—"I consider that the agitation means eventually disaster for the Empire. From what I have seen and heard, I feel convinced that the story, as told in the Press, represents but one-half of the real facts. Extreme measures are necessary if British rule is to refrain predominant in India. Mahometans have no logical excuse for disaffection. It was the advance of the British that alone saved the Mahometan Empire from dismemberment, but all the other races should be loyal for similar reasons , for it is only under British rule that the joint interests of India races can he Mended harmoniously, and the social and moral welfare of the vast population of India be promoted."

div.head: Casino San Stefano
div.p: Dimanche 30 Juin 1907 a 11 heures du matin, grand concert Symphonique donné par l'orchestre du Casino, composé de 40 musiciens dirigés par Monsieur Bracale. 1st pro gramme est très artistique et entièrement composé de morceaux nouveaux pour l'Egypte. Le programme sera publié demain.
Prochainement aura lieu aussi le début des artistes chanteurs engagés à Milan pour la saison. Parmi ceux-ci nous citons l'excellente soprano Mademoiselle Pitirollo.

div.head: Cassa Di Sconto
div.p: The evaluation of the assets of the Cassa now being made by some connoisseurs from the four local banks, Anglo-Egyptian, Imperial Ottoman, Deutsche-Orient and Comptoir Nationale d'Escompte, will be ready, it is hoped, by to-morrow night. Up to now about £1,100,000 worth of assets have been valued and tho "déchats" come to about thirteen percent. On these "déchats" it is quite possible that a certain percentage may be eventually collected.

Harari Pasha is not representing Sir Ernest Cassel in the investigation now proceeding into the position of the Cassa at Alexandria. The role of Sir Ernest Cassel in the whole matter is quite unofficial, and the interest he has manifested in the situation is solely inspired by his connection with Egyptian affairs generally.

div.head: A STRANGE PANACEA.
div.p: Our excellent contemporary "La Réforme," in its issue of Wednesday under tho heading of "La Banque d'Etat et les Biens Libres" propound» as a solution for the present, and as a panacea against a future monetary crisis, a scheme so chimerical in conception, utterly unsound financially and so dangerous to the credit of the country if it were ever seriously entertained, that we may he thankful that in their financial advisors the Government possess men of ripe experience and sound judgement. We must confess to a feeling of disappointment when we find so important an organ of public instruction as our esteemed confrère thoroughly misreading the lessons of the crisis now happily passing away and we must warn our readers of the danger in listening to such crude proposals.

Our contemporary starts with the debatable premise that Egypt possesses insufficient gold for the enterprises which she has undertaken for some years past ; and he then quotes Mr. Alfred Neymarch's plea for larger gold reserves in France as a justification for demanding more gold for Egypt. Although we do not see the parallel between the two countries in the matter we think it well to reply that Mr. Neymarch's objection to the free flow of capital in the form of gold from France, is that the value of rents and home stocks have become depreciated : however, he tails to show any diminution in the income of holders of stock. We contend that gold must lie unfettered and allow to circulate freely Confine it and it will either hurst its barriers or it will stagnate and create financial malaria : its flow can no more be impeded by ill-considered legislation than the waves of the Atlantic by tho broom of Mrs. Partington, Space forbids us to do more than refer to the great Secretan collapse in Paris many years ago in utter refutation of Mr. Neymarch's theories of hoarding gold.

Anyhow, we fail to understand our contemporary's complaint that the amount of specie imported for some years past has been insufficient for the enterprise of the country We hold on the contrary that it has been more than sufficient and that speculators have been attempting to pour the proverbial gallon into the proverbial half-gallon measure with the invariable result. The crisis of the last few weeks has not arisen from scarcity of gold but from want of confidence. Destroy confidence or credit at any time and the result will be that value in fixed investments will heroine depreciated and the value of gold will appreciate enormously in purchasing power. Restore confidence and the operation will be reversed.

Now the customs returns prove that the imports of gold during the past three years have enormously exceeded the exports, a clear indication of a large addition to the stock of yellow metal in the country. But when the question is asked "Where has the surplus gone?" we are gravely told that it has been melted down for ornaments for native women or buried under ground

Allowing that some considerable percentage has been thus absorbed, we incline to the belief that a large amount remains in the vaults of the banks, where it has always been. While speculation flourished, the bankers advanced to their customers but when the depression came, the position changed the hanks called in their advances, and the gold was no longer at the disposal of their customers. That many unfortunate people have been ruined lines not admit of doubt; in their simplicity they leaned oil the support of the banks which has pierced them to the quick.

We pass over the proposal of our contemporary that the Government shall on the security of public lands authorize the National Bank of Egypt Ltd. to make a further emission of notes for the requirements of the country Article No. 5 of the Statutes of the National Bank stipulates for a cash reserve of one half and one half securities taken at par against the notes issued, and this article it is suggested to repeal or amend.

We venture to assort that a more dangerous and mischievous proposition could not possibly be suggested. The sanctity of the issue department of the National Bank of Egypt most be preserved inviolable. The natives of the country are gradually being educated to the issue of bank notes and no greater disaster could befall Egypt than anything calculated in the slightest manner to even threaten their credit

Our contemporary asks whether it is prudent to leave the financing of the coming cotton crop to the moment when it will arrive at market. Decidedly not ; but we imagine that this matter may lie safely left in the hands of those representative firms who have hitherto managed the shipment of the crop.

In conclusion our contemporary ask of its suggestion. "Is it possible?" Our reply is an unequivocal negative. "Is it legal X' Certainly not, nor is it over likely to become so while H.B.M.'s Consul General is the responsible adviser to H.H. the Khedive.

div.head: A DRASTIC REMEDY
div.p: "Al Lewa" makes a really remarkable proposal — the liquidation of every new company that has not effected anything. Our Nationalist contemporary remarks :—

Veterans are unanimous in supporting the opinion we expressed since the commencement of the present crisis that it is necessary for the shareholders of every company recently formed which has absorbed great sums of money, without effecting any obvious project or carrying out any enterprise, to demand that it should be liquidated, so as to know where the money has gone to.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: On his arrival at Constantinople the Khedive was received by two aides-de-Camp of the Sultan, and his Imperial Majesty afterwards went on board to meet the Khedive.

div.head: THE MEDITERRANEAN FLEET. Arrival at Alexandria
div.p: The Mediterranean Fleet was sighted off Alexandria shortly before eight o'clock this morning and soon after nine they were off Ras-el-Tin lighthouse, where the "Queen," "Venerable," "Prince of Wales," and "Irresistible" anchored, the "Lancaster," Suffolk," and "Barham" coming into harbour. At midday Admiral Sir Charles Drury and H.R.H. Prince Louis of Battenberg called on Mustapha Pasha Ibadi at the Government. On its arrival the fleet was greeted by the customary salute from the guns of Fort Saleh.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Papayanni liner "City of Khios" sailed from Tripoli on the 26th inst., and is expected to arrive here with passengers and mails tomorrow.
The S.S. "Carib Prince" arrived at Manchester from Alexandria via Dunkirk on the 26th inst.

div.head: PORT SAID. Trade During the Past Year.
div.p: The report of Mr, Cameron, H.B.M.'s Consul General at Port Said, on the trade and commerce of that port during 1906, has just been issued by the Foreign Office, from which we extract the following
Import dues.
Import duties have been reduced from 8 to 4 per cent, ad valorem on coal, liquid fuel, characol, timber, petroleum, cattle, sheep and and goats, and on frozen meat.
Coal.

The coal imports in 1906 amounted to 1,3.75,718 tons, or some 87,000 tons more than in 190,7. Of this some 1,241,000 tons were supplied to ships in transit, and about 114,000 tons were taken inland :—

Of the 114,000 tons sent inland, about half was dust and small coal, and half North Country large coal. It was chiefly carried by sailing barges either to Ismailia or to Damietta. Only about 10,000 tons went by rail, as it was necessary to transport it from the quay to the station : but now that sidings have been made from the main line to the quays, it will be interesting to note the development of the transport of coal into the interior by rail.
Exports.

The total exports from Port Said have fallen from 401,060 L.E. in 1905 to 290,766 L.E in 1906, owing principally to the decrease in the export of cigarettes to Germany which has hitherto been the chief customer and distributing centre for the Continent
Cigarettes.

Out of a total export trade in cigarettes from Egypt of .790 metric tons, valued at 46.7,863 LE., Port Said exported 260 tons, valued at 208,122 RE., Alexandria exported 291 tons (232,85.7 LE.) and Suez 39 tons (24,8.76 L.E.).
Of the 260 tons from Port Said, .70 tons went to the United Kingdom, 64 toms to India and 112 rims to Germany for distribution on the Continent.

The total value of frozen meat brought to this harbor from Australia and New Zealand, for transit or import, was 50,574l in 1906 as compared with 31,000l in 1905 and 19,000l. in 1904 Until recently the meat was supplied almost entirely for the u<o of ships in transit, hut a very promising trade has sprung up with the interior, and will most probably increase in importance owing to the fluctuating supply of live stock from Syria.
Motor launches.

Motor launches are coming more and more into use at this port, both the Canal Company and the Egyptian authorities, os well as the various shipping agents, employing them for communicating with ships in the harbor and Canal.
Clothing.

The demand for articles of clothing has shown a marked increase during the [vast year Ready made suits of drill, cotton or cloth, overcoats, coloured shirts, collars, ties, lints, and boots and shoes appear to be in demand among the native and Levantine population. Only the cheapest class of article has any large sale, there being but a small demand for superior goods.
Athletic outfits.

Although various kinds of athletic sports, such as tennis, cricket, hockey and foot hail, are indulged in at Port Said, none of the requisites are obtainable in the town. There should be a certain demand for such articles, and athletic outfitters might do well to enter into communication with suitable firms here for the sale of their goods.
Progress and development of Port Said

During the [last year considerable progress has been made in the harbour works mentioned in my last report. An extensive basin is being dredged on the eastern side of the Canal for the use of colliers and petroleum ships. When this is ready the Abbas basin (on the western side now occupied by the colliers) will be available for ships to load or discharge general cargo from or to the interior of Egypt. At the same time the Cherif basin on the western side is being more than doubled in size and deepened to 30 feet, and in addition to the bonded warehouses already completed wharves with railway sidings arc being constructed.

The Suez Canal Company's workshop will he removed to the eastern side of the harbour, where a new village will he established for workmen, and the tract of land at present occupied by the workshop» will lie dredged away and dee pencil, making a new large twain of the arsenal with wharves reaching up to the railway station.

The Menzaleh Canal and Navigation Compares have dredged a deep and wide channel across the shallow water of the lake; and established a daily service of ferry boats between Port Said (Karpooti) and Matarieh, the eastern point of the fertile province of Mansonran (Dakahlieh). The voyage takes about three hours, and, in co operation which the- light railway of the Société Anonyme des Chemins de Fer de la Basse Egypte, this route across the lake ought to prove of the greatest value in connecting Port Said with the north of the Delta. It is proposed to continue this channel as for as Port-Said station and ultimately to connect it with a lock into the maritime canal, the present sweet water canal passing under the channel by means of a syphon. Another channel has been dredged, connecting Matarieh with Damietta.
Dimensions of Suez Canal.
The navigable dimensions of the Suez Canal are now practically double what they were 20

years ago, the superficies of the vertical profile having.boon increased from 320 to 680 square metres in the ordinary channel and to 740 square metres in the numerous gares or crossing places, the dredging being so carried out os to exceed the limits originally agreed upon.

From 1898 to 1904, owing to the increasing size of ships, larger gares were begun, some 20 in number, at intervals of 3 miles, each gare having an effective length of 820 yards with approaches of 328 yards at either end. At each gare tire bottom width of the Canal is .70 yards, the width at the water-level over 100 yards, the depth of the gare itself being 31 feet.
Faking the Canal as a whole, its width on the water-level in the northern half is from 100 to 120 yards, and in the southern half from 80 to 100 yards.
Draught.
In 1902 the maximum draught was raised from 25 feet 7 inches to 26 feet 3 inches (8 metres). On January 1, 1906, the maximum was raised to 27 feet (H metres 23 centims).
Canal Dues.
The original tariff for laden ships was 10 fr. Per ton in 1869.

This was raised to 13 fr. in 1874, but was lowered 1/2 fr. per year from 1877 to 9 fr. in 1893, and to 8 1/2 fr. in 1903. On January 1, 1906, the tariff was reduced to 7 fr. 76 c. For ships in ballast the tariff has always been 2 fr. 50 c. less. The 10 fr. rate for passengers has never been changed.
Lighthouse dues.
From January 1, 1906, the lighthouse dues in the Red Sea have been reduced from 14 to 10 millims. per ton for ships under 800 tons, and from 7 to 5 millims. for ships over that tonnage.
Suez Canal traffic and navigation.

3,97,3 vessels of a net tonnage of 13,445,504 tons passed through the Canal in 1906 as compared with 4,116 vessels of 13,134,10,7 tons in 190.7, showing a decrease of 41 vessels but an increase of 311,399 tons. Of these 3,975 vessels 2.948 were merchant vessels (including 83 in ballast), 888 were mail steamers mid 139 warships and Government transports.

The transit receipts were 108,161,896 fr, as against 113,866,797 fr. in 190.7, a decrease of 5.704,901 fr. owing to the tariff having been reduced on January 1, 1906, to 7 fr. 76 c. per ton from the previous rate of 8 fr. 50 c.
Mean net tonnage.

The mean net tonnage has risen from 1,000 tons in 1871 (when the Canal was a narrow "ditch" to 1,500 tons in 1880, to 2,000 tons in 1890, to 2,800 tons in 1900, to 3,190 tons in 1905 and to 3,382 tons in 1906.
Duration of transit.

The mean duration remains about the same, namely, 18 hours for all vessels, but the general effective rate for mail steamers is 15 hours. The length of the Canal is 160 kiloms. (100 miles), and the ordinary rate of speed is 10 kiloms. (6} miles) per hour. The use of the electric light is practically universal, amounting to 97 per cent.
British shipping.

Out of the total of 3,97.7 vessels 2,333 were British, a decrease of 1.71 vessels as compared with 1905. British net tonnage was 8,299,931 tons, a decrease of 57,000 Ions as compared with 1905. The British percentage of that number of vessels is 58.7 and of the tonnage 61.7.
These figures apply only to the general total, hut if we consider only merchant vessels, the British percentages are 71.3 in number of vessels and 74.7 in the net tonnage.
During tho last few years the German percentage in number of ships 1ms risen from 13 to 14.8 and in tonnage from 15 to 16.
France, the Netherlands, Austria-Hungary, Italy and Norway combined furnish a total of 18.8 per cent, of the vessels and 16.1 percent, of the tonnage.
Repatriation of Russian troops.

After the ratification of the treaty of peace between Russia and Japan, nine Russian ships of war returned home, and large contracts were made for the repatriation of troops from Vladivostok. By the end of May 11-4,000 troops passed through the Canal in 62 transports, of which 28 were British ships mid 11 were German. The total number of Russian troops thus repatriated during 1906 amounted to 127,000 officers and men. Sometimes as many as three large transports were in Port Said harbour together, with 6,000 men on board but no unpleasant incident or case of misconduct occurred. The success of the entire series of transits reflects the greatest credit on the Canal administration and pilotage, as well as on the Egyptian local authorities and harbour police. Reference is here made to this subject in order, to show how thoroughly well the Suez Canal is policed and administered by the Egyptian Government and the Canal Company. No accident, such as the stranding or collision of a belligerent vessel, is to be recorded in the last nine years, during the Spanish-American war, the Boer war, or the Russian-Japanese war.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The announcement of Saba Pasha's name among the Birthday Honours in this morning's telegrams will be received with general satisfaction by both the European and native sections of the population of Egypt, for few officials in the service of the Egyptian Government have made themselves so generally popular as the late Postmaster General.
Birch Pasha is returning from Europe the 10th proxo.
Count von Berndsdorff, the German Diplomatic Agent and Consul General is leaving tomorrow by the Austrian Lloyd steamer.
Mgr. Photios, Greek Patriarch at Alexandria, left for Cyprus on Wednesday last to attend the Synod for the election of an Archbishop for that Island.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujour d'hui à 11 1.1/2).

Bien qu'il eût affluence de monde à lu corbeille, l'ouverture de ce mutin a été relativement calme Les cours n'en ont pas moins continué \ hausser à la suite des marchés européens. Mais les transactions ne contribuant pas a soutenir las prix, il y a eu soudain un fléchissement qui est allé s'accentuant jusqu'à U clôture où une reprise a enfin eu lieu et nous a ramené sensiblement nu mémo niveau qu'hier. La note dominante de la matinée a été le défaut d'entrain et la rareté des affaires qui se sont limitées, comme importance, aux Agricole, National Bank, Delta Land, Estates et Crédit Franco-Egyptien.

De nouvelles tentatives de traiter la Cassa di Sconto n'ont guère eu plus d'effet que les jours précédents. Il parait cependant que les vendeurs réduisent leurs exigences puisque les prix inscrits en clôture sont inférieurs de 5 fr. à ceux d'hier, soit 45 fr. l'ancienne action et 60 fr. la nouvelle. A noter pour cette dernière qu'un versement île ôO fr. restant à effort lier, la valeur exacte du titre revient ainsi à 10 fr. soit une différence de 3,î fr. avec l'ancienne, ce qui nous parait disproportionné.
Tandis que la Banque d'Athènes perd I fr. 50 à 115 1/2, la Banque d'Orient regagne 2 fr. à 113.
L'Agricole fléchit de S 3 16 à H 1/16, et la Delta Light de U 1/4 à 9 1/8, tandis que la National Bank s'avance de 20 à 20 I 8 et la Daira de 13 3/4 à 14.

En hausse également l'Obligation ancienne Crédit Foncier de 314 à 315, les Nungovich Hotels de 16 à 17 1/2, l'Union Foncière de 4 à 4 7/8, le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 4 1/2 a 4 9/16, la fondateur United de 3 à 3 1 4.
Les Tramways d'Alexandrie reviennent, ni contraire, de 160 à 155, la Deferred Delta de 11 1/2 à 11 la Building Lands de 2 7,8 à f 3/4.
Tandis que l'action Comptoir fléchit de 3 l'ancienne et 3 1,8 la nouvelle à 3 I 8 et .» respectivement, sa part de fondateur mont< de 3 1/2 à 3 3/4. Ce mouvement en sens iif verse a commene hier.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Cotton Mill retombent de 3 3 à 3, la Levant de 5/8 à les Ritz Hotels de 43/16 à 3/4 et la fondateur Zariffa de 9 à 8, pendant que les Market progressent de 17/9 à 18 et la Levico de 3/8 à 7/16.

Nous devons a la vérité de dire qu'au nombre de ces fluctuations, il en est de purement nominales attendu que des intéressés les one fait, inscrire en clôture, alors que la plupar des courtiers étaient partis et qu'il n'y aval plus de contre-partie pour leur répondre. Ces là du reste une pratique quotidienne trop répandue à notre bourse, pratique qui ese cause en partie des fluctuations aussi énormes que fantaisistes qu'on constate souvent notre cote aussi bien à la hausse qu'à la laisses En ce qui concerne la Cotisa di Sconto, on espère que la situation sera établie demain soir. Jusqu'à présent les chiffres contrôlés at teignent environ 1.100.000 livres, sur lesquels-on escompte à peu près 13% de perte.

div.head: Ciculaire H. De Vries et Boutigny. Notes et Critiques.
div.p: Le Caire, Jeudi 27 Juin.

Le taux de l'escompte libre a Londres s'est tenu hier a 3 7/8 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolide anglais est reste invarie a 84 ½ de meme que l'Unifie a 100 ¼. La National Bank a encore hausse d'une livre a 20 3/8, L'Agricole de demi-livre a 8 3/8 la Daira Sanieh de ¼ a 14 et la Delta Light de 3/8 a 9 3 4.
A Paris, le Credit Foncier Egyptien a progresse de 1 franc a 683. La Banque d'Athenes est demuree inchangee a 114.

Les cours de cloture de Londres, joints a la persistance des runeurs suivant lesquelles il faudrait decidement s'attendre a une solution satisfaisante du probleme de la Casse de Sconto, nous ont valu ce matin un excellent marche. La plupart des cours se sont inscrits en avance et, qui plus est il y a eu un tres bon courant d'affaires. Il faut espere que ces dispositions favorables se mantindendront et qu'elles s'accentueront meme. Il suffraint peur-etre pour cela qu'une liquidation a l'amiable, basee sur le projet expose dans notre Circulaire d'avant-hier, fut substituee a une liquidation judiciare de la Casse di Sconto. Tous les efforts paraissent converger actuellement vers ce but, et il y a vraiment lieu de faire des voeux pour qu'ils aboutissent a un resultat postif.
Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National a hausse jusqu'a 20 1/16 pour finir a 20. L'Agricole a cloture a 8 3/16.
Le Credit Foncier s'est maintenu a 680. L'Union Fonciere a progresse a 4 ¾. Les Allotments se sout etablis a 2 5/16 et leur part a 68. Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire sont remontees a 180.
Dans le groupe des valeurs, la Delta Land a passe de 1 11/16 a 2 1/16-1/8. Les Estates se sont raffermis a 7/8. LEs New Egyptian ont avance a 15 sh. 9 et les Walker and Maimarachi a 0 5/16 - 3/8.
Nous detachons de notre correspondence de Londres en date du 21 Juin, le passage suivant:

"Les titres egyptiens traites au Stock Exchange ont eu, cette semaine, un marche tres mouvemente. Par suite d'ordres de ventetransmis d'Egypte, la valeur principalement atteinte a eta la National Bank. De 19 7/8, prix auquel nous l'avions laissee le 14 elle a cloture ce soir a 16 5/8 apres avoir ete ramenee a 15 ¾ au plus bas ce matin. L'Agricole a fait preuve de p lus de resistance, mais les autres titres du groupe ont ete malmenes a l'avenant.

"Cette depression exageree continue a attirer l'attention du portefeuille european, et la plupart des acheteurs actuels sont de forte envergure. Ces bas cours deviennent excessivement interessants, car ils representent une baisse de 30 a 50% depuis le mois de Mars dernier. Il est possible que, par suite de nouveaux ordres de vente, les prix subissent un recul additionnel; mais il est, d'autre part, certain que les cours actuels sont assez allechants pour qu'on en profite dans une certaine masure, quitte a faire des achats ulterieurs dans le cas d'une nouvelle baisse."
L'assemblee generale ordinaire de la Compagnie Immpbiliere d'Egypte, qui s'est tenue le 20 Juin courant au siege social a Bruxelles a approuve a l'unaimite les comptes de l'exercice 1906.

Ainsi que nous l'avons deja annonce la benefice net se monte a Frs. 1,350,784.64. Il a ete prelve une forte somme pour le fonds de prevision et Frs. 65,289.24 pour la reserve statutaire. Les dividendes ont ete fixes a Frs. 25 par action de capital et Frs. 40 par part de fondateur, payables a partir du fer Juillet prochain a l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank et a la Societe Generale Egyptienne au Caire. Une somme de Frs. 28,672.60 a ete reportee a nouveau.

A diverses questions qui lui ont ete poses, le counseil a repondu pour ce qui est des gros reports a nouveau, que cette meausre de prevoyance ne saurait nuire aux actionnaires, qui retrouveront ces sommesdancs le prochain bilan. Les benefices realises eussent certainement permis de repartir des dividendes beaucoup plus eleves puisque la moitie environ du benefice net realise a ete reserve mais malgre crela les dividendes sont fort remunerateurs. Le conseil estime que se prudence consolide l'avenir et met la Societe a l'abri de teus les aleas.

The "Egyptian Gazette" d'hier publie une lettre d'un actionnaire de l'Egyptian Estates Co. qui se plaint des retards apports a la convocation de l'assemble generale, promise a bref delai par une communication officielle publice dans les premiers jours d'Avril dernier.
La "Gazette" annonce que M. Montagu Summers, directeur de la Societe, est parti avant-hier pour Londres et que, probablement, es voyage se rattache a la reunion incessante de l'assemblee.

L'assemblee generale annuelle de l'Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co sera tenue dans le cours du mois prochain. Le benefice net de l'exercice ecoule s'eleverait a 106,000 pounds, soit 16,000 pounds de plus que pour l'exercise precedent. On s'attend, par consequent a un dividende superieur a celui de l'annee derniere.

L'assemblee generale ordinaire de l'Express Nile Streamers Co. est convoquee pour le jeudi 11 Juillet prochain a 3 h. p.m. au siege social au Caire. A l'orde du jour: rapport du conseil d'administration; presentaion des comptes du premier exercise; nominations statutaires, etc. Le depot des titres doit etra effectue le 8 Juillet 1907 au plus tard.

div.head: THE HAGUE CONFERENCE. Contraband At Sea.

div.p: The British delegates We submitted to the Conference a proposal to abolish contraband at sea. The right of visit should be then merely exercise»! to establish the neutral character of merchant ships. The restriction imposed by blockades would still continue, also the prohibition of the sale of actual potential warships to belligerents. The British proposal regarding a prize court embraces an international permanent court which would hear appeals where the interests of neutrals would be affected. The German 'proposal is more complicated and provides for the formation of a special court after the outbreak of hostilities. France has proposed that hostilities must be preceded by a declaration war or an ultimatum with a conditional deduction.

The British contraband proposal is mainly due to the danger of enforcing the right of search, to the difficulty of defing contraband, and to the facilities which Continental powers possess fur importing contraband over land. (Reuter)

div.head: HOUSE OF COMMONS. Evicted Tenants Bill.

div.p: Mr. Birrell introduced the Evicted Tenants Bill, which was read for the first time. It empowers estates commissioners to acquire land compulsorily for the reinstatement of 2000 evicted tenants who would be regarded as purchasers under the Land Act. (Reuter)
It is officially stated that the Emperor and Empress of Germany will visit the King and Queen at Windsor in November. (Reuter)

div.head: REPATRIATION OF CHINESE. Depression on the Rand.

div.p: The depression has been aggravated by the forthcoming repatriation of the Chinese. The mining and other houses are retrenching. Land and house property has further depreciated. (Reuter)

div.head: KING'S BIRTHDAY HONOURS. Honours for Egypt.

div.p: Honorary Knight of the Grand Cross of St. Micheal and St. George, Saba Pasha, formerly Post-Master General, Egypt. Companion of the Order of St. Michael and St George, Mr. W. E. Brunyate, Adviser to the Ministry of Justice, Egypt. (Reuter)
There is no confirmation that the French have occupied any point whatever in the Tripolitan neighborhood. The maintenance of the status quo is reported for all the posts. (Havas)
Admiral Brochetti, commander of the Italian squadron, has been received by the Sultan. (Havas)
On the occasion of the deposit of the Budget in the Chamber, M. Beck promised social reforms. (Havas)
Riots have broken out in several towns. Several persons were killed or wounded. (H.)
The ex-minister Nasi has been called before the Senate met in High Court. (Havas)
The Khedive has arrived.
(Later). The Khedive called on the Sultan and afterwards visited his mother. (Reuter)
The "Pyramus" has been refloated: she is undamaged. (Reuter)

div.head: THE OCCUPATION OF EGYPT.
div.p: A SECRET HISTORY.

Mr. Wilfrid Blunt's Secret History of the English Occupation of Egypt has too close a bearing on politics to be reviewed at length. That the author is playing with fire he knows, as may be seen by his frank admissions, such as the following : —

"I cannot wholly regret the course I took. I made, of course, many mistakes, and I feel that I am in considerable measure responsible for the determination the Nationalists came to to risk their country's fortune on the die of battle."

A certain undue violence and rashness of statement is one of the "mistakes"; but the author is to be commended for the honesty which causes him to leave the dangerous passages for the judgment of the public. Among those is one on p. 497, which shows that Mr. Blunt—we hope only "in half-earnest"—agreed with a Nationalist leader that it would have been better "that we should cut off the Khedive's head." The book seems to have been written some little time ago, and revised only here and there within the last few months. There is an allusion to the retirement of Lord Cromer, but, on the other hand, "Sir Thomas Sanderson" still appears as being "now head of the Foreign Office.' The important point, however, is that if we are to have such a volume, it is right that we should have the exact truth as it appears to Mr. Blunt. On the other hand, it is, we should think, impossible that he should have received the permission of Sir Charles Rivers Wilson, Sir Edward Hamilton, and other distinguished officials, whose letters are given at full length, to publish their accounts of all that was passing when they were in the public service ; and the printing of such letters, during the life of all concerned, without permission, is n practice almost unknown in England though common u|ion the Continent. The letters of Sir Edward Hamilton were written by him for Gladstone while he was private secretary to the Prime Minister, and are obviously in many cases of an official nature. The references to conversations in Downing Street with at least two of the Prime Minister's secretaries are even more indiscreet, if possible, than the printing of the letters. One secretary, for example, assures the author "that my interference with Malet's diplomacy was in no way resented by his chief." Sir Edward Malet is still living, and such publication is calculated to make the courtesies of official life impossible. Another ambassador who is still serving this country in a great capital is also quoted as the authority for highly confidential statements. Mr. Wilfrid Blunt is so frank in his account of the Nationalist movement that he proves the ease of the Government, against which he was acting in becoming the London adviser of those against whom this country was carrying on operations. Thus, for example, he establishes a real case for the bombardement

of the forts at Alexandria. There were many who were still doubtful as to the accuracy of Admiral Sir Beauchamp Seymour's statements. Everything lias been put into the volume, and we find for the first time a basis for the French charge that Tel-el-Kebir was won by "the cavalry of St George," by British gold-pieces. It amounts to little, but it is there, and the story put into the mouths of the Egyptian primes is worth some inquiry. It is stated that money was paid in pieces bearing the St George, but false, and made up to contain lead. It ought to have been easy at the time, and might be possible now, to trace the origin of such coins.
The following extracts will be of interest: -
THE MOUFETTISH'S END.
This account of the end of the Moufettish is alleged by Mr. Blunt to have been given him by Sir Rivers Wilson :—

The details given me by Wilson were as follows : Ismail had been in the habit, in his dealing with the various European Commissioners, whom he had from time to time invited to enquire into his financial affairs, of concealing as far as was possible from them the extreme truth of his senseless extravagances, and with his minister Ismail Sadyk's help had once more now, as on previous occasions, presented to the new official commission a false statement of his debts.

The pressure, however, on him was severe, as the commission had received a hint, if I remember rightly, from Riaz Pasha, that they were being befooled on this point and he fearing that the whole truth would come out, and when the matter should be fully gone into by the commission his minister might tell the facts, determined to be beforehand with him and make of him his scapegoat and victim. He took the execution of the deed to his own hands. It was his custom with his Minister, with whom he was on the closest possible terms of personal friendship, to call some times for the old man in the afternoon at the Finance Office and take him for a drive with him to Shubra or to one or other of his palaces ; so on this occasion he did and suspecting nothing, the minister mounted with him and they drove together to the Gesireh Palace and there got down and entered. No sooner however were they inside, than Ismail on some pretext left him alone in one of the saloons and immediately sent to him his two younger sons Husseyn and Hassan and his aide-de-camp Mustapha Bey Fehmy, when the princes struck and insulted the unarmed Minister and hustled him on board one of the vice regal steamers which was lying with steam up beside the quay, and there, though not without a vigorous resistance, the old man was despatched. According to Wilson, the actual doer of the deed was Mustafa Bey, acting under the Khedive's order, and he added that the truth had been disclosed through the young aide de-camp falling ill of a fever soon after, and telling it in his delirium. I have reason, however, to believe that as tar as Mustafa's personal act went this was a mistake, though the rest of the facts have been fully confirmed to me, and that the Mouffetish was handed over by Mustafa to Ishak Bey, in whose charge he perished, though whether at once or a little later is uncertain. Some say that Ismail Sadyk was thrown, as many another had been thrown, with a stone tied to his feet into the Nile, others, that he was conveyed alive as far as to between Wady Halfa and Dongola and there strangled. All that is quite beyond dispute is that once on board the steamer he was never seen again alive, and that the steamer having gone up the river, it was some weeks later officially announced that the Moufettish was away ill Upper Egypt for a change of air and ultimately that lie had there taken to drink and died. It is also certain that Mustafa, a mild young man and unused to scenes of violence, and being himself, as the Moufettish was of Algerine extraction, was so horrified at the role he had been ordered to play in it that he had a long and dangerous illness. It was this experience that a year later caused him to take the part he did against his master Ismail and ultimately to join Arabi in the earlier phases of the revolution of 1881-2. He is the same Mustafa Fehmy who has for so many years filled the office of Prime Minister in Egypt
NUBAR JUDGED.
The influence of Nubar Pasha on Ismail is severely criticized. In reference to the Khedive's policy of providing for his immense expenditure by raising, loans, Mr. Blunt remarks :—

Here his worst councillor and evil genius had been Nubar Pasha, the Armenian financier, who by a strange inversion of ideas has come to be regarded by a certain class of Egyptian patriot. Nubar was, however, in fact, the one man who, more than any other after Ismail himself, was responsible for Egypt's financial ruin.

Commissioned by his master to find him money at any cost to meet his extravagant wants he raised loan after loan for him in Euro|>e on terms, which realized for him hardly more titan 60 per cent of the capital sums he inscribed himself for as a debtor, while he, Nubar, pocketed as commission several millions sterling. Of the 96 millions, nominally raised in this way, it has been calculated that only some 54 reached Ismail's hands.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY. Cricket.
div.p: BEHERA LAND Co., v. MESSRS. CARVER AND PEEL'S (combined).

An interesting match was played on Tuesday on the A.C.C. ground between Messrs. Carver Bros, and Co., and Peel and Co., (combined) versus The Behera Land Co. Birley and Haselden started for Messrs. Carver and Peel's, and soon began scoring freely, the score being taken to 127 before Haselden was caught. H.B. Carver then joined Birley and 55 runs were added before Birley was dismissed for a well-played 96. The third wicket fell with the score at 246. H.B. Carver was the next to leave for a lively bat somewhat lucky 73, and the remainder were soon dismissed for a total of 292.

With this formidable total and an hour and three quarters left for play, Kinder and Tabor opened the innings for the Behera Co. After 25 minutes patient cricket, the first wicket fell for 36 and matters looked serious for the Behera Co. with 5 wkts down for 100 and 45 minutes to play. Dealtry then joined Kinder who had been playing very nice cricket — the former played steadily till stumps were drawn when the score stood at 214 for no farther lass, the match thus ending in a draw. Kinder played through the innings for a most useful 136 hitting 24 fours and 2 sixes.
Mr. Poster's kindness in providing tea was much appreciated by a considerable and enthusiastic attendance, and it is generally hoped that the match may become an annual fixture.
MESSRS. CARVER & CO., AND PEEL & CO.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limits - free discussion.
Where are the police?
To the editor of the "Egyptian Gazette"

Sir,— A strange anomaly exists in Alexandrin. It seems that the strenuous efforts of our zealous authorities to suppress vice in every form have proven up to the present hut failures or as the French say : "trous dans l'eau" trous dans le N 100... or elsewhere. Of course we must attribute all this to the Capitulations.

The "purification scheme" simply aborted in a "white elephant", for the particular vice in question is more rampant than ever. Gambling is supposed to be suppressed, but I know from a trustworthy source that the police blandly wink at this clandestine traffic.

But really our authorities ought to open their eyes to a game which is carried on in the open air, in the face of the mighty elements; the sky, the stars, the ocean, the city and... the police combined. I allude to the shooting gamble.

We know that at home racing is allowed, but then we have the satisfaction of knowing that it is all above-water work, and that every precaution is taken to protect the public from being thus dealt with. Such, however, is not the case with the Tir Espagnol.

Their manner of procedure is this : (First of all I must mention that every woman in the show is a crack shot and if it only depended on her own will, would not miss the target once in the 24 hours. All that seeming nervousness, momentary hesitation, languidness, prostration, leaning against the table to have a steadier grip of the carbine are all feigned to dupe the public.)

People bet on red, white, yellow and green. There are two men one after the other, yelling for all they are worth "Qui pari sur Trilla", "Messieurs, il y a à faire sur le rouge et le blanc" "Personne ne pari plus" He looks around with a gleam of satisfaction, which he cannot help evincing over the amount the "house' will amass on the dupes that foolishly throw away their money. Meanwhile a silent and unpretentious individual amongst the crowd beckons the waiter and orders a number of tickets on one of the colours (he will not always choose the most favourable because that would cause suspicion.) This is not the only "acolyte" of the house — there are many; otherwise that would also cause suspicion. Of course a sign invisible to the public is given and the house scores.

No, it is time this farce should be put an end to. If the concern were honest and genuine it might be tolerated on the same basis as racing, but it is nothing more nor less than a swindling fraud and can only be catalogued with card-sharping.

Of course you will say: "why do the idiots go and bet" and you are right. But on the other hand most of those that bet are new comers who unsuspiciously bet, thinking they are placing their money on a "coup d'adresse" and not on a cunningly contrived scheme. Besides the public taxpayer has a right to be protected from these open tricksters.
Yours truly
Unsatisfied.
Alexandria, June 27.

div.head: EXPENSIVE WHISKERS
div.p: A lady has just won an action which she brought against a certain gentleman of this city for personal injuries sustained through defendant kissing her.
The gentleman, it appears, rejoices in a luxuriant though somewhat wiry growth of whiskers, and in kissing the plaintiff he scratched her cheek. Inflammation set in and the lady suffered much pain.
Damages were assessed at 15 pounds.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu'au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 24 juin 1907.
